citeinfo.title: Vicksburg-Jackson Confining Unit: Alabama, Arkansas, Louisiana, Missouri, Mississippi, Tennessee 2006-2008
Digital Surfaces and Thicknesses of Selected Hydrogeologic Units within the Mississippi Embayment Regional Aquifer Study (MERAS)

descript.abstract: Digital hydrogeologic surface of the Vicksburg-Jackson Confining Unit in Arkansas, Alabama, Louisiana, Missouri, Mississippi, and Tennessee. The hydrogeologic unit dataset contains 414 rows and 394 columns representing 1-mile grid spacing. In general, limitations of data interpolation included areas of sparse geophysical log control points, log datums not clearly defined for some logs, unknown exact extent of each hydrogeologic unit in subcrop, interpolation limitations, and values averaged over 1-mile grid spacing.
descript.purpose: The purpose of these data is to provide a digital map of the surface of select hydrogeologic units within the Mississippi Embayment aquifer system.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the data set's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

citeinfo.title: Digital Surfaces and Thicknesses of Selected Hydrogeologic Units within the Mississippi Embayment Regional Aquifer Study (MERAS)

attracc.attraccr: The correlation altitude on the geophysical logs and the altitude of the interpolated digital hydrogeologic surface was determined at every location a geophysical log control point existed. The differences between the geophysical log control point and the interpolated digital hydrogeologic surface at each location represents how accurate the interpolated digital hydrogeologic surface is to the "real world" geophysical log control point. Mean differences (correlation altitude on the geophysical logs minus interpolated digital hydrogeologic surface altitude) is the average difference between the unit correlation altitudes on the geophysical logs and the altitudes of the interpolated digital hydrogeologic surfaces at the location of the geophysical log control point. Minimum and maximum differences are those measured between the unit correlation altitudes on the geophysical logs and the altitudes of the interpolated digital hydrogeologic surfaces; absolute mean error is the error between the unit correlation altitudes on the geophysical logs and the altitudes of the interpolated digital hydrogeologis surfaces.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.
dataqual.complete: The interpolated digital hydrogeologic surface covers the extent to which the presumed extent of the hydrogeologic unit in subcrop exits, and therefore, covers the extent at which the geophysical log control points exist. Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

procstep.procdesc: See Methods section of report Digital Surfaces and Thicknesses of Selected Hydrogeologic Units within the Mississippi Embayment Regional Aquifer Study (MERAS), SIR 2008-5098.

mapproj.mapprojn: USA Contiguous Albers Equal Area Conic USGS version (ESRI Full Name: USA_Contiguous_Albers_Equal_Area_Conic_USGS_version)

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

overview.eaover: This digital surface is one of nine selected Tertiary and younger age hydrogeologic units within the Mississippi embayment aquifer system which were created using more than 2,600 geophysical logs for an area that covers approximately 70,000 square miles and encompasses parts of eight states. The digital surfaces were developed to define and display the hydrogeologic framework for the Mississippi Embayment Regional Aquifer Study (MERAS). The digital surfaces also provide a foundation of the selected hydrogeologic units for development of a steady-state and transient regional ground-water flow model of the Mississippi embayment aquifer system from the top of the Midway confining unit upwards to land surface. The ground-water flow model is under development as part of the U.S. Geological Survey Ground-Water Resources Program.
overview.eadetcit: Hart, R.M., Clark, B.R., and Bolyard, S.E., 2008, Digital surfaces and thicknesses of selected hydrogeologic units within the Mississippi Embayment Regional Aquifer Study (MERAS): U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5098, 33 p.
